title: Local structural studies of Sr-buffered Si surface prepared with pulsed laser deposition

author: Tjaša Parkelj, Advanced Materials Department, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: Hello everybody, thank you for the introduction so I would like to invite you to a mini Nano construction site.
You know the core of your pencil and the diamonds are both made of carbon atoms, but the pencil is so soft you can write with it and the diamond is so hard you can cut glass.
So the only difference between them is their crystal structure.
So structure plays an important role in the properties of materials.
If you take some oxygen atoms in some metal atoms and combine them in a certain way, you can make them make a material that can transform mechanical energy into electrical energy.
So you could put this kind of material in the soul of your shoe and.
I don't know charge your mobile phone or warm your feet.
As my colleague mentioned before but or all our electronic devices are based on Silicon and silicone on its own.

Doesn't have such rich properties, so if we could somehow combine this functional oxides with the existing Silicon technology, we could make electronic devices that could have very interesting properties and applications in our life so.
But there isn't.

It's not so easy to combine these two materials together, we can just glue them together, but Luckily there are ways to grow oxide materials, atomic layer by atomic layer on top of Silicon in our group where developing a procedure on how to grow oxide materials on Silicon using pulsed laser deposition.
So yeah, we get to play with lasers and laser pulses.
AR.
Fired at the material, which kind of makes a tiny explosion.
So this explosion transforms the material onto our substrate and this is how the thin film grows.
And if we choose the right parameters, we can make a very ordered structure which will have the properties that we desire.
Well, if everything goes right, but that's not always the case, and unfortunately.
This kind of growth is a very dynamic process and we don't have a camera that could look at the atoms during the growth, so this is where I come in.
I use this.
National microscope to examine the growth of the films.
So with every step of the way.
So when we grow one film, I can examine the surface, the structure of the surface by using an atomically sharp tip that scans the surface.
And because this tip interacts with the electrons of the atoms that form the surface, we can form an image and.

This image can have atomic resolution and in this way we can tell something about the structure because you know when you're building a house, it's very important that you have good foundations before you start the next level of the House, so bye.
This images help us to understand how the structure looks like and gives us clues on how to tune the growth parameters so we can make good structures with good properties.
So this functional oxides can someday be in our electronic devices with interesting capabilities.
So thank you for that.
